citeinfo.origin: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program
citeinfo.title: Seamless 30-Meter Digital Elevation Model for Rocky Mountain National Park

pubinfo.publish: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program

descript.abstract: This data is a seamless Digital Elevation Model (DEM) that depicts the surface elevation in and around Rocky Mountain National Park. It is in ARC/INFO lattice format. The resolution for this data is 30 meters per cell. This data covers a 25 quad area centered on ROMO. The 25 7.5 minute USGS quads covered are: Clark Peak, Chambers Lake, Comanche Peak, Pingree Park, Crystal Mountain, Mount Richthofen, Fall River Pass, Trail Ridge, Estes Park, Glen Haven, Bowen Mountain, Grand Lake, McHenrys Peak, Longs Peak, Panorama Peak, Trail Mountain, Shadow Mountain, Isolation Peak, Allens Park, Raymond, Granby, Strawberry Lake, Monarch Lake, Ward, and Gold Hill. For more information refer to the USGS_DEM User's Guide available on-line at: <URL:http://edcwww.cr.usgs.gov/glis/hyper/guide/usgs_dem>.
descript.purpose: Data used and/or developed by the Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program is used in the protection and Management of Rocky Mountain National Park.

idinfo.useconst: Not for use at scales greater than 1:24000

cntperp.cntorg: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.0.0.535

attracc.attraccr: The attribute accuracy is deductively estimated to be "good". If a higher proof of data accuracy is required, do not use this data. User is advised to FULLY and CAREFULLY READ the "DISTRIBUTION LIABILITY" section of this metadata before using this data.

dataqual.complete: Data is considered complete. Some datasets are parkwide in scope, while others were developed and/or updated to address specific management concerns within particular spatial coordinates. Users of this data are advised to FULLY and CAREFULLY READ the "DISTRIBUTION LIABILITY" section of this

horizpa.horizpar: Horizontal accuracy varies depending on the source of individual components within the data. Data derived from USGS data (DLGs, DEMs, DOQQs) are assumed to meet National Map Accuracy standards, though extensive experience in using USGS data for the Rocky Mountain National Park area has shown that many data coponents have spatial errors exceeding the National Map Accuracy standards. Data produced from GPS (Global Positioning System) field data is assumed to be spatially accurate to within 2-5 meters.

lineage.procstep:
Rocky Mountain National Park (ROMO) acquired 25 Level 1 Digital Elevation Model (DEM) data files in 1990. The USGS DEM data files were imported into Geographic Resource Analysis Support System (GRASS) software using the "m.dem.extract" command. Areas of "no-data" gaps were identified, and these gaps were filled using a 3x3 matrix filter (for gaps 1 cell wide) or a 5x5 matrix filter (for gaps 2 or 3 cells wide).
The process of filtering the gaps involved creating a region (mapextent) 1 cell wider than the gap on both sides of the gap and running the matrix filter on that small amount of data using the GRASS command "r.mfilter". The cell file containing the results of the filtering was then patched back into the DEM coverage using the GRASS command "r.patch".
No smoothing was performed to reduce the horizontal striping which is characteristic in Level 1 DEM data and which is evident in this data.
The GRASS raster data was converted to an ARC/INFO lattice coverage using the ARC/INFO command IMAGEGRID. The ARC/INFO TABLES module was used to add a FEET item and to populate that item. This was accomplished by multipying the VALUE item by 3.280839895.
For detailed information about how the individual DEM data files were created see the USGS_DEM User's Guide available on-line at: <URL:http://edcwww.cr.usgs.gov/glis/hyper/guide/usgs_dem>.
19900101 Rocky Mountain National Park (ROMO) acquired 25 Level 1 Digital Elevation Model (DEM) data files in 1990. The USGS DEM data files were imported into Geographic Resource Analysis Support System (GRASS) software using the "m.dem.extract" command. Areas of "no-data" gaps were identified, and these gaps were filled using a 3x3 matrix filter (for gaps 1 cell wide) or a 5x5 matrix filter (for gaps 2 or 3 cells wide). The process of filtering the gaps involved creating a region (mapextent) 1 cell wider than the gap on both sides of the gap and running the matrix filter on that small amount of data using the GRASS command "r.mfilter". The cell file containing the results of the filtering was then patched back into the DEM coverage using the GRASS command "r.patch". No smoothing was performed to reduce the horizontal striping which is characteristic in Level 1 DEM data and which is evident in this data. The GRASS raster data was converted to an ARC/INFO lattice coverage using the ARC/INFO command IMAGEGRID. The ARC/INFO TABLES module was used to add a FEET item and to populate that item. This was accomplished by multipying the VALUE item by 3.280839895. For detailed information about how the individual DEM data files were created see the USGS_DEM User's Guide available on-line at: <URL:http://edcwww.cr.usgs.gov/glis/hyper/guide/usgs_dem>.

procstep.procdesc: The base template for this metadata created using ROMOMETA.AML, a locally modified version (modified June 1998) of FGDCMETA.AML ver. 1.2 05/14/98 on ARC/INFO data set /db/topo/elev_dem
Metadata converted from html to xml

overview.eaover: The first two items in the value attribute table (VAT) are automatically generated by ARC/INFO software. Contact ESRI or read their literature for detailed descriptions of their internal file structure. ESRI (Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc.) can be reached at: <URL:http://www.esri.com>. (Link valid July 1998). The VALUE item is a numeric field that is populated by a value that represents the elevation in meters. The COUNT item is a numeric field that is populated by a value that represents the number of cells that have a given VALUE. The FEET item is a numeric field that is populated by a value that represents the elevation in feet and was created by multiplying the VALUE item by 3.280839895.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
